medium:
Ko-imari ware
Porcelain with overglaze enamels
title: Ko-Imari Leaf Shaped Dish, one of five
text: Japanese potters became an important source of porcelain decorated in the Chinese manner for the European market in the early decades of the 17th century. By the 1660's and 70's, however, Japanese shapes and designs became popular among both foreign and domestic buyers. Tea masters prized elegant plates such as these for use in <I>kaiseki<I>, cuisine served in conjunction with the tea ceremony.
description: leaf shaped dish; pale green with brown rim; inside of dish dark green starburst bottom center; curved dark green shape left of starburst; curved dark blue shape above starburst
creditline: The Louis W. Hill, Jr. Fund
